member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ActionFormat.AxisMax
member.summary: Maximum value for the range of scaled data to be returned for all axes. This value is ignored for a specific action axis if the DIA_NORANGE flag is set in Diaction.dwFlags. This value is valid only for axis actions and should be set to zero for all other actions. It is used as the Diproprange.lMax value to set the range property on an absolute axis when the action map is applied using Inputdevice9Setactionmap.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ActionFormat.AxisMin
member.summary: Minimum value for the range of scaled data to be returned for all axes. This value is ignored for a specific action axis if the DIA_NORANGE flag is set in Diaction.dwFlags. This value is valid only for axis actions and should be set to zero for all other actions. It is used as the Diproprange.lMin value to set the range property on an absolute axis when the action map is applied using Inputdevice9Setactionmap.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ActionFormat.BufferSize

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData
member.summary: Contains buffered device information. This structure is used with the Inputdevice9Getdevicedata and the Inputdevice9Senddevicedata methods.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData.ApplicationData
member.summary: Application-defined action value assigned to this object in the last call to Inputdevice9Setactionmap. This is the value in the uAppData member of the Diaction structure associated with the object. Ignore this value if you are not using action mapping. When the structure is used with the Inputdevice9Senddevicedata method, this member must be zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData.Data
member.summary: Data obtained from or sent to the device. For axis input, if the device is in relative axis mode, the relative axis motion is reported. If the device is in absolute axis mode, the absolute axis coordinate is reported.For button input, only the low byte of DwData is significant. The high bit of the low byte is set if the button was pressed; it is clear if the button was released.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData.Offset
member.summary: The offset into the current data format of the object whose data is being reported.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData.Sequence
member.summary: Microsoft® DirectInput® sequence number for this event. All input events are assigned an increasing sequence number. This enables events from different devices to be sorted chronologically.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.BufferedData.TimeStamp
member.summary: System time at which the input event was generated, in milliseconds. This value wraps around approximately every 50 days. See Remarks. When the structure is used with the Inputdevice9Senddevicedata method, this member must be 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Device.Poll
member.summary: Retrieves data from polled objects on a Microsoft® DirectInput® device. If the device does not require polling, calling this method has no effect. If a device that requires polling is not polled periodically, no new data is received from the device. Calling this method causes Microsoft® DirectInput® to update the device state, generate input events (if buffered data is enabled), and set notification events (if notification is enabled).

member.summary: Various properties you can get or set on a device.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetApplicationData(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the application-defined value associated with an in-game action.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetCalibrationPoints(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves calibration points used for the adjustment of incoming raw data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetDeadZone(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a value for the dead zone of a joystick, in the range from 0 through 10,000, where 0 indicates that there is no dead zone, 5,000 indicates that the dead zone extends over 50 percent of the physical range of the axis on both sides of center, and 10,000 indicates that the entire physical range of the axis is dead. When the axis is within the dead zone, it is reported as being at the center of its range.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetGranularity(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the input granularity. Granularity represents the smallest distance over which the object reports movement. Most axis objects have a granularity of one; that is, all values are possible. Some axes have a larger granularity. For example, the wheel axis on a mouse can have a granularity of 20; that is, all reported changes in position are multiples of 20. In other words, when the user turns the wheel slowly, the device reports a position of 0, then 20, then 40, and so on. This is a read-only property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetKeyName(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the localized key name for a keyboard key

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetLogicalRange(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the range of the raw data returned for axes on a HID. Devices can return negative values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetPhysicalRange(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the range of data for axes as suggested by the manufacturer of a HID. Values can be negative. Normally DirectInput returns values from 0 through 0×FFFF, but the range can be made to conform to the manufacturer's suggested range by using the Range property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetRange(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the range of values an object can possibly report. For some devices, this is a read-only property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetSaturation(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a value for the saturation zones of a joystick, in the range from 0 through 10,000. The saturation level is the point at which the axis is considered to be at its most extreme position. For example, if the saturation level is set to 9,500, the axis reaches the extreme of its range when it has moved 95 percent of the physical distance from its center position (or from the dead zone).

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.GetScanCode(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the scan code for a keyboard key.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.SetApplicationData(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the application-defined value associated with an in-game action.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.SetCalibrationPoints(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CalibrationPoint[])
member.summary: Sets calibration points used for the adjustment of incoming raw data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.SetDeadZone(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the value for the dead zone of a joystick, in the range from 0 through 10,000, where 0 indicates that there is no dead zone, 5,000 indicates that the dead zone extends over 50 percent of the physical range of the axis on both sides of center, and 10,000 indicates that the entire physical range of the axis is dead. When the axis is within the dead zone, it is reported as being at the center of its range. This setting can be applied to either the entire device or to a specific axis.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.SetRange(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.InputRange)
member.summary: Sets the range of values an object can possibly report.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.SetSaturation(Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ParameterHow,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the value for the saturation zones of a joystick, in the range from 0 through 10,000. The saturation level is the point at which the axis is considered to be at its most extreme position. For example, if the saturation level is set to 9,500, the axis reaches the extreme of its range when it has moved 95 percent of the physical distance from its center position (or from the dead zone). This setting can be applied to either the entire device or a specific axis.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.AutoCenter
member.summary: Specifies whether device objects are self centering. This setting applies to the entire device, rather than to any particular object.

member.summary: Retrieves the friendly product name of the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceProperties.TypeName
member.summary: Predefined property that retrieves the type name of a device. For most game controllers, this is the registry key name under REGSTR_PATH_JOYOEM from which static device settings can be retrieved, but predefined joystick types have special names consisting of a number sign (#) followed by a character dependent on the type. This value might not be available for all devices.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectObject.Start(System.Int32)
member.summary: Begins playing an effect. If the effect is already playing, it is restarted from the beginning. If the effect has not been downloaded or has been modified since its last download, it is downloaded before being started. This default behavior can be suppressed by passing the DIES_NODOWNLOAD flag.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectObject.Start(System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectStartFlags)
member.summary: Begins playing an effect. If the effect is already playing, it is restarted from the beginning. If the effect has not been downloaded or has been modified since its last download, it is downloaded before being started. This default behavior can be suppressed by passing the DIES_NODOWNLOAD flag.

member.summary: Stops playing an effect.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_CONDITION.A reference to an array of Dicondition structures for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure. The number of elements in the array must be either one, or equal to the number of axes associated with the effect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.DeadBand
member.summary: Region around LOffset in which the condition is not active, in the range from 0 through 10,000. In other words, the condition is not active between LOffset minus LDeadBand and LOffset plus LDeadBand.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.NegativeCoefficient
member.summary: Coefficient constant on the negative side of the offset, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000. If the device does not support separate positive and negative coefficients, the value of LNegative

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.NegativeSaturation
member.summary: Maximum force output on the negative side of the offset, in the range from 0 through 10,000.If the device does not support force saturation, the value of this member is ignored.If the device does not support separate positive and negative saturation, the value of DwNegativeSaturation is ignored, and the value of DwPositiveSaturation is used as both the positive and negative saturation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.Offset
member.summary: Offset for the condition, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.PositiveCoefficient
member.summary: Coefficient constant on the positive side of the offset, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Condition.PositiveSaturation
member.summary: Maximum force output on the positive side of the offset, in the range from 0 through 10,000.If the device does not support force TermSaturation, the value of this member is ignored.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ConstantForce
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_CONSTANTFORCE.The structure describes a constant force effect.A reference to a single Diconstantforce structure for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ConstantForce.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ConstantForce.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ConstantForce.Magnitude
member.summary: The magnitude of the effect, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000. If an TermEnvelope is applied to this effect, the value represents the magnitude of the TermSustain. If no envelope is applied, the value represents the amplitude of the entire effect.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_CUSTOMFORCE.The structure describes a custom or user-defined force.A reference to a Dicustomforce structure for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce.Channels
member.summary: Number of channels (axes) affected by this force. The first channel is applied to the first axis associated with the effect, the second to the second, and so on. If there are fewer channels than axes, nothing is associated with the extra axes.If there is only a single channel, the effect is rotated in the direction specified by the rglDirection member of the Dieffect structure. If there is more than one channel, rotation is not allowed.Not all devices support rotation of custom effects.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce.SamplePeriod
member.summary: Sample period, in microseconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.CustomForce.Samples
member.summary: Total number of samples in the RglForceData. It must be an integral multiple of the CChannels.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceCaps.FFMinTimeResolution
member.summary: Minimum time, in microseconds, that the device can resolve. The device rounds any times to the nearest supported increment. For example, if the value of DwFFMinTimeResolution is 1000, the device would round any times to the nearest millisecond.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceCaps.FFSamplePeriod

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceCaps.HardwareRevision

member.summary: Number of axes available on the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceCaps.NumberButtons
member.summary: Number of buttons available on the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceCaps.NumberPointOfViews
member.summary: Number of point-of-view controllers available on the device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation
member.summary: Carries information required to display a device image or an overlay image with a callout. This structure is passed to the Inputdevice9Getimageinfo method as an array within a Dideviceimageinfoheader structure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.CalloutLine
member.summary: Array of POINT structures that specify coordinates of the points describing a callout line. A callout line connects a device control to a caption for the game action. Each line can have from one to four segments. This member is valid only if the DIDIFT_OVERLAY flag is present in DwFlags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.CalloutRectangle
member.summary: RECT structure that describes the rectangle in which the game action string is displayed. If the string cannot fit within the rectangle, the application is responsible for handling clipping. This member is valid only if the DIDIFT_OVERLAY flag is present in DwFlags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.Overlay
member.summary: Rectangle, using coordinates relative to the top-left pixel of the device configuration image, in which the overlay image should be painted. This member is valid only if the DIDIFT_OVERLAY flag is present in DwFlags.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.Flags
member.summary: Flag that describes the intended use of the image.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.ImagePath
member.summary: Fully qualified path to the file that contains an image of the device. The file format is given in DwFlags. If no image is available for the device, this member will be set to NULL. If so, the application is responsible for enumerating controls on the device and displaying a default listing of actions to device controls (similar to the method used by most applications before Microsoft® DirectX® 8.0).

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.ObjectId
member.summary: Control identifier, as a combination of DIDFT_* flags and an instance value, to which an overlay image corresponds for this device. Applications use the DIDFT_GETINSTANCE and DIDFT_GETTYPE macros to decode this value to its constituent parts. This member is valid only if the DIDIFT_OVERLAY flag is present in DwFlags.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.TextAlign
member.summary: DWORD value that specifies the alignment of the text in the rectangle described by the RcCalloutRect member. Must be one horizontal alignment flag combined with one vertical alignment flag. This member is valid only if the DIDIFT_OVERLAY flag is present in DwFlags.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformation.ViewId
member.summary: For device view images (DIDIFT_CONFIGURATION), this is the identifier of the device view.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader
member.summary: Contains information about device images. Used in the Inputdevice9Getimageinfo method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.ImageInformationArray
member.summary: Pointer to a buffer that receives an array of Dideviceimageinfo structures describing all the device images and views, overlay images, and callout-string coordinates.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.Buttons
member.summary: DWORD variable that receives the number of buttons on the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.NumberAxes
member.summary: DWORD variable that receives the number of axes on the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.POVs
member.summary: DWORD variable that receives the number of point-of-view controllers on the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceImageInformationHeader.Views
member.summary: DWORD variable that receives the number of views of this device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance
member.summary: Describes an instance of a Microsoft® DirectInput® device. This structure is used with the Input9Enumdevices, Input9Enumdevicesbysemantics, and Inputdevice9Getdeviceinfo methods.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.DeviceSubType
member.summary: Device type specifier. The least-significant byte of the device type description code specifies the device type. The next-significant byte specifies the device subtype. This value can also be combined with DIDEVTYPE_HID, which specifies a Human Interface Device (TermHid).

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.DeviceType
member.summary: Device type specifier. The least-significant byte of the device type description code specifies the device type. The next-significant byte specifies the device subtype. This value can also be combined with DIDEVTYPE_HID, which specifies a Human Interface Device (TermHid).

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.FFDriverGuid
member.summary: Unique identifier for the driver being used for force feedback. The driver's manufacturer establishes this identifier.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.InstanceGuid
member.summary: Unique identifier for the instance of the device. An application can save the instance GUID into a configuration file and use it at a later time. Instance GUIDs are specific to a particular computer. An instance GUID obtained from one computer is unrelated to instance GUIDs on another.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.InstanceName
member.summary: Friendly name for the instance, for example, 'Joystick 1.'

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.ProductGuid
member.summary: Unique identifier for the product. This identifier is established by the manufacturer of the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.ProductName
member.summary: Friendly name for the product.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.Usage
member.summary: If the device is a Human Interface Device (HID), this member contains the HID usage code.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceInstance.UsagePage
member.summary: If the device is a Human Interface Device (HID), this member contains the HID usage page code.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance
member.summary: Describes a device object instance. This structure is used with the Inputdevice9Enumobjects method to provide the Dienumdeviceobjectscallback callback function with information about a particular object associated with a device, such as an axis or button. It is also used with the Inputdevice9Getobjectinfo method to retrieve information about a device object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.CollectionNumber
member.summary: The Human Interface Device (TermHid) link collection to which the object belongs.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.DesignatorIndex
member.summary: An index that refers to a designator in the HID physical descriptor. This number can be passed to functions in the HID parsing library (Hidpi.h) to obtain additional information about the device object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Dimension
member.summary: A Human Interface Device (HID) code for the dimensional units in which the object's value is reported, if known, or 0 if not known.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Exponent
member.summary: The exponent to associate with the dimension, if known. Dimensional units are always integral, so an exponent might be needed to convert them to nonintegral types.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Flags
member.summary: Flags describing other attributes of the data format. This value can be one of the following:

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.ForceResolution
member.summary: The force resolution of the actuator associated with this object. The returned value represents the number of gradations, or subdivisions, of the maximum force that can be expressed by the force-feedback system from 0 (no force) to maximum force.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.MaxForce
member.summary: The magnitude of the maximum force that can be created by the actuator associated with this object. Force is expressed in newtons and measured in relation to where the hand would be during normal operation of the device.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Name
member.summary: Name of the object, for example, 'X-Axis' or 'Right Shift.'

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.ObjectId
member.summary: An index that refers to a designator in the HID physical descriptor. This number can be passed to functions in the HID parsing library (Hidpi.h) to obtain additional information about the device object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.ObjectType
member.summary: Unique identifier that indicates the object type. This member is optional. If present, it can be one of the following values:

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Offset
member.summary: Offset in the native data format of the device. The native data format corresponds to the raw device data. The DwOfs member does not correspond to the device constant, such as DIJOFS_BUTTON0, for this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.ReportId
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.Usage
member.summary: The HID usage associated with the object, if known. HIDs always report a usage. Non-HIDs can optionally report a usage; if they do not, the value of this member is 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.DeviceObjectInstance.UsagePage
member.summary: The Human Interface Device (HID) usage page associated with the object, if known. HIDs always report a usage page. Non-HID devices can optionally report a usage page; if they do not, the value of this member is 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect
member.summary: Used by the Inputdevice9Createeffect method to initialize a new Inputeffect object. It is also used by the InputeffectSetparameters and InputeffectGetparameters methods.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.Periodic
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_PERIODIC.The structure describes a periodic effect.A reference to a single Diperiodic structure for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.Duration
member.summary: The total duration of the effect, in microseconds. If this value is INFINITE, the effect has infinite duration. If an TermEnvelope has been applied to the effect, the TermAttack is applied, followed by an infinite TermSustain.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.Flags
member.summary: Flags associated with the effect. This value can be a combination of one or more of the following values:

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.Gain
member.summary: The gain to be applied to the effect, in the range from 0 through 10,000. The gain is a scaling factor applied to all magnitudes of the effect and its envelope.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.SamplePeriod
member.summary: The period at which the device should play back the effect, in microseconds. A value of 0 indicates that the default playback sample rate should be used. If the device is not capable of playing back the effect at the specified rate, it chooses the supported rate that is closest to the requested value.Setting a custom DwSamplePeriod can be used for special effects. For example, playing a sine wave at an artificially large sample period results in a rougher texture.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.StartDelay
member.summary: Time (in microseconds) that the device should wait after a InputeffectStart call before playing the effect. If this value is 0, effect playback begins immediately. This member is not present in versions prior to Microsoft® DirectX® 7.0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.TriggerButton
member.summary: The identifier or offset of the button to be used to trigger playback of the effect. The flags DIEFF_OBJECTIDS and DIEFF_OBJECTOFFSETS determine the semantics of the value. If this member is set to DIEB_NOTRIGGER, no trigger button is associated with the effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.TriggerRepeatInterval
member.summary: The interval, in microseconds, between the end of one playback and the start of the next when the effect is triggered by a button press and the button is held down. Setting this value to INFINITE suppresses repetition. Support for trigger repeat for an effect is indicated by the presence of the DIEP_TRIGGERREPEATINTERVAL flag in the dwStaticParams member of the Dieffectinfo structure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Effect.UsesEnvelope
member.summary: Used by the Dieffect structure to specify the optional TermEnvelope parameters for an effect. The TermSustain level for the envelope is represented by the dwMagnitude member of the Diperiodic structure and the lMagnitude member of the Diconstantforce structure. The sustain time is represented by dwDuration member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation
member.summary: Used by the Inputdevice9Enumeffects and Inputdevice9Geteffectinfo methods to return information about a particular effect supported by a device.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.DynamicParams
member.summary: Zero or more DIEP_* values denoting parameters of the effect that can be modified while the effect is playing. For a list of possible values, see InputeffectGetparameters. If an application attempts to change a parameter while the effect is playing and the driver does not support modifying that effect dynamically, the driver is permitted to stop the effect, update the parameters, then restart it. For more information, see InputeffectSetparameters.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.EffectGuid
member.summary: Identifier of the effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.EffectType
member.summary: Zero or more of the following values:

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.Name
member.summary: Name of the effect, for example, 'Sawtooth up' or 'Constant force'.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectInformation.StaticParams
member.summary: Zero or more DIEP_* values describing the parameters supported by the effect. For example, if DIEP_ENVELOPE is set, the effect supports an envelope. For a list of possible values, see InputeffectGetparameters. It is not an error for an application to attempt to use effect parameters that are not supported by the device. The unsupported parameters are ignored.This information is provided to enable the application to tailor its use of force feedback to the capabilities of the specific device.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectStatus.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectStatus.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.EffectStatus.Playing
member.summary: The effect is playing.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope
member.summary: Used by the Dieffect structure to specify the optional TermEnvelope parameters for an effect. The TermSustain level for the envelope is represented by the dwMagnitude member of the Diperiodic structure and the lMagnitude member of the Diconstantforce structure. The sustain time is represented by dwDuration member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.AttackLevel
member.summary: Amplitude for the start of the envelope, relative to the baseline, in the range from 0 through 10,000. If the effect's type-specific data does not specify a baseline, the amplitude is relative to 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.AttackTime
member.summary: The time, in microseconds, to reach the TermSustain level.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.FadeLevel
member.summary: Amplitude for the end of the envelope, relative to the baseline, in the range from 0 through 10,000. If the effect's type-specific data does not specify a baseline, the amplitude is relative to 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Envelope.FadeTime
member.summary: The time, in microseconds, to reach the fade level.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect
member.summary: Describes data for a force-feedback effect stored in a file. It is used in conjunction with the Inputdevice9Enumeffectsinfile and Inputdevice9Writeeffecttofile methods.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect.EffectStruct
member.summary: Pointer to a Dieffect structure containing information about the effect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect.EffectGuid
member.summary: Unique identifier of the effect type. This can be one of the standard GUIDs defined in Dinput.h, such as GUID_ConstantForce, or one created by the designer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.FileEffect.Name
member.summary: Name of the effect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.InputRange.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.InputRange.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState
member.summary: Describes the state of a joystick device. This structure is used with the Inputdevice9Getdevicestate method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetASlider
member.summary: Extra axis accelerations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetButtons
member.summary: Array of buttons. The high-order bit of the byte is set if the corresponding button is down, and clear if the button is up or does not exist.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetFSlider
member.summary: Extra axis forces.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetPointOfView
member.summary: Direction controllers, such as point-of-view hats. The position is indicated in hundredths of a degree clockwise from north (away from the user). The center position is normally reported as -1; but see Remarks. For indicators that have only five positions, the value for a controller is -1, 0, 9,000, 18,000, or 27,000.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetSlider
member.summary: Two additional axes, formerly called the u-axis and v-axis, whose semantics depend on the joystick. Use the Inputdevice9Getobjectinfo method to obtain semantic information about these values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.GetVSlider
member.summary: Extra axis velocities.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.ARx
member.summary: X-axis angular acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.ARy
member.summary: Y-axis angular acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.ARz
member.summary: Z-axis angular acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.AX
member.summary: X-axis acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.AY
member.summary: Y-axis acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.AZ
member.summary: Z-axis acceleration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FRx
member.summary: X-axis torque.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FRy
member.summary: Y-axis torque.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FRz
member.summary: Z-axis torque.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FX
member.summary: X-axis force.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FY
member.summary: Y-axis force.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.FZ
member.summary: Z-axis force.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.Rx
member.summary: X-axis rotation. If the joystick does not have this axis, the value is 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.Ry
member.summary: Y-axis rotation. If the joystick does not have this axis, the value is 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.Rz
member.summary: Z-axis rotation (often called the rudder). If the joystick does not have this axis, the value is 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VRx
member.summary: X-axis angular velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VRy
member.summary: Y-axis angular velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VRz
member.summary: Z-axis angular velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VX
member.summary: X-axis velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VY
member.summary: Y-axis velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.VZ
member.summary: Z-axis velocity.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.X
member.summary: X-axis, usually the left-right movement of a stick.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.Y
member.summary: Y-axis, usually the forward-backward movement of a stick.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.JoystickState.Z
member.summary: Z-axis, often the throttle control. If the joystick does not have this axis, the value is 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState
member.summary: Describes the state of a mouse device that has up to four buttons, or another device that is being accessed as if it were a mouse device. This structure is used with the Inputdevice9Getdevicestate method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.GetMouseButtons
member.summary: Array of buttons. The high-order bit of the byte is set if the corresponding button is down.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.X
member.summary: X-axis.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.Y
member.summary: Y-axis.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.MouseState.Z
member.summary: Z-axis, typically a wheel. If the mouse does not have a z-axis, the value is 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat
member.summary: Describes a device object's data format for use with the Inputdevice9Setdataformat method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.DeviceType
member.summary: Device type that describes the object. It is a combination of the following flags describing the object type (axis, button, and so forth) and containing the object-instance number in the middle 16 bits. When requesting a data format, the instance portion must be set to DIDFT_ANYINSTANCE to indicate that any instance is permissible, or to DidftMakeinstance(n) to restrict the request to instance n. See the examples under Remarks.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.Flags
member.summary: Zero or more of the following values:

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.Offset
member.summary: Offset within the data packet where the data for the input source is stored. This value must be a multiple of 4 for DWORD size data, such as axes. It can be byte-aligned for buttons.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.ObjectDataFormat.SourceGuid
member.summary: Unique identifier for the axis, button, or other input source. When requesting a data format, making this member NULL indicates that any type of object is permissible.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_PERIODIC.The structure describes a periodic effect.A reference to a single Diperiodic structure for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.Magnitude
member.summary: Magnitude of the effect, in the range from 0 through 10,000. If an TermEnvelope is applied to this effect, the value represents the magnitude of the TermSustain. If no envelope is applied, the value represents the amplitude of the entire effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.Offset
member.summary: Offset of the effect. The range of forces generated by the effect is LOffset minus DwMagnitude to LOffset plus DwMagnitude. The value of the LOffset member is also the baseline for any envelope that is applied to the effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.Period
member.summary: Period of the effect, in microseconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.Periodic.Phase
member.summary: Position in the cycle of the periodic effect at which playback begins, in the range from 0 through 35,999. See Remarks.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.RampForce
member.summary: Contains type-specific information for effects that are marked as DIEFT_RAMPFORCE. The structure describes a ramp force effect.A reference to a single Dirampforce structure for an effect is passed in the lpvTypeSpecificParams member of the Dieffect structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.RampForce.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.RampForce.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.RampForce.End
member.summary: Magnitude at the end of the effect, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.RampForce.Start
member.summary: Magnitude at the start of the effect, in the range from -10,000 through 10,000.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectInput.SemanticsInstance.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.

member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.
